questions.neutral: Did the city spit you out again?

hobby.message: Political literature age better than policy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: City's rough lately. Can't keep out of it, I suppose.
I fold origami, when I can find decent paper.
Curfews make that tricky these days. Lighting’s unreliable.
Whole routine feels exposed now, even for something harmless like folding.
Yeah. Hard to avoid the grind these days.
I usually make complex origami—used ration cards and scrap forms, mostly.
It’s quiet. Needs patience. Not much patience left in the city lately.
Curfews, restrictions… harder to find space or feel at ease doing it now.
Feels pointless sometimes, honestly.
Pretty much. Sometimes I escape by folding origami—little animals, spirals, a swan now and then.
Something about the paper, the neat lines… keeps my mind organized.
With power cuts and security always around, I have to fold at work.
Not sure if that's allowed, but it’s quieter than home.
Guess it’s harmless, but lately I flatten everything away fast.
Feels strange being secretive over paper, you know?
Yeah, the city never tires of chewing people up, does it?
I lose myself folding origami—makes complex patterns with ration cards or discarded admin forms.
It sharpens focus, like solving a puzzle in silence.
Since the curfews and all, I can’t fold at home anymore—too dark, too risky to have extra light.
So I stay late at the Directorate and let my hands work while I analyze the mess.
Even that feels watched, like someone could report me. Or think it’s code.
I hide the finished pieces. City’s made me secretive about everything, even paper.
Yeah, spat out and shaken around, usual lately.
My thing’s intricate origami—spirals, cranes, even modular stuff, all from ration cards or ration slips.
Started years ago, just after the system rolled out, when I needed a coping ritual.
Folding helps me control my thoughts; hands moving, mind focusing away from Council paranoia.
Now with curfews, power rationing, night sweeps, even a harmless hobby like mine feels risky.
Last week I folded a nautilus spiral at my desk with blackout sirens droning. Left it hidden in my file folder.
Used to trade pieces with a neighbor, but post-crackdown, even showing them off risks being flagged.
Funny; in Stenograd, paper animals might get you watched as much as protest leaflets do.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Origami helps. It's quiet.
Not easy now, with all the curfews.
Power cuts ruin my timing, sometimes I stop before I'm done.
Security asks questions about anything unusual on desks.
I just keep it simple, nothing worth noticing.
Origami helps keep things steady. Better than most things.
Hard to focus lately with the Directorate around every corner.
I used to leave models on my desk. Not safe now.
With blockades and checks, even scrap paper feels suspicious.
Had to shred my last big one after a sweep came through.
It's not relaxing if you’re watching the door.
Yeah, still better than anything in the med locker. Keeps my hands busy.
I mostly fold from ration cards or Directorate notices. The paper's reliable.
Lost a few pieces during the last blackout—folding by flashlight didn’t go well.
Curfews mean less time to work on big models.
Security doesn't like anything left behind after hours. I flatten and hide everything now.
Kind of feels like hiding evidence for something harmless.
Strange how even small things can feel risky lately.
Yeah, origami's still my best anchor. Keeps my head from spiraling.
The way you crease folds, get sharp edges, it’s like building order out of scraps.
Lately ration cards are the best paper—hard to get extras since redistribution.
After curfews started, I sometimes fold at work just to feel normal.
Almost got questioned last week for 'idle lingering' after I didn't pack up at once.
Had to flatten my finished nautilus and stuff it in a file—didn't want anyone tracing it.
Feels ridiculous to hide paper animals like state secrets.
But it’s routine now. Safety in habits, I guess.
Yeah, origami’s kept me sane since the first BCI rollouts. I need the structure.
I used to leave models in the kitchen at home for the neighbors to take—can’t now.
Ration card paper is nice and crisp, but watching every scrap gets tiring.
The curfews made my block so quiet, sometimes folding is the only thing that calms me.
Lost a whole stack last blackout—folded in the dark, the shapes got ruined.
Security keeps sweeping through; I even had to shred a sea dragon to avoid questions.
Sometimes I think someone’s tracking who folds what—paranoid, maybe, but nothing feels private.
It's strange—our whole lives cataloged, but something simple like origami makes me feel like myself.
Funny how something so harmless feels dangerous now.
